title: Young woman who had tumours all over her face 'no longer has to hide' after op
text:

A young woman who had tumours growing on her face says she "no longer has to hide" after undergoing a series of surgeries thanks to kind strangers.

Generous charities raised more than £14,000 to fly Natalia Apaseray, 26, from Indonesia to Australia to be treated for a rare genetic disorder that led to her being tormented by children who would throw rocks at her.

Ms Apaseray was born with a severe form of neurofibromatosis, which causes benign tumours to grow on her skin and along her nerves.

She had a mass of tumours that left her feeling so ashamed that she would cover up her face when she would go out in public at home, where there was no medical help available to her.

(Image: Facebook/The Natalia Project)

People would stare and she would be tormented by locals.

On one occasion she was found hiding in a bin as children threw rocks at it, said plastic surgeon Dr Michael Kernohan, who operated on Ms Apaseray in Sydney.

A group of surgeons performed a series of "complex and mammoth" operations to remove the mass and they, along with the patient, have now revealed the results.

(Image: Facebook)

Ms Apaseray has thanked the Rotary clubs who raised the funds and the staff who operated on her at Liverpool Hospital in suburban Sydney.

She told news.com.au: "I felt a lot of shame growing up in Jayapura because of my face.

"I am so happy to be going back to see my community. I no longer feel the need to hide my face.

(Image: Facebook/The Natalia Project)

"There is no way I can pay everyone back for how they have helped."

Surgeons in Australia became aware of her plight after she was found by a member of a US medical team in February 2018.

The American contacted Peter Gray, then-president of the Rotary Club of Phnom Penh, and asked for help.

Mr Gray said in an interview with the Liverpool City Champion newspaper last year: "No-one deserves to live like this."

(Image: Facebook/The Natalia Project)

Rotary clubs in Cambodia and Australia raised more than £14,000 to fly Ms Apaseray to Sydney for multiple surgeries and cover local transport and accommodation.

The hospital treated her as a humanitarian patient and the medical team donated their time.

After her first surgery in May, she underwent major facial reconstruction during a seven-hour operation in June.

Doctors removed a large portion of the right side of her face and rebuilt her nose, mouth and eyelid.

Dr Kernohan said hailed Ms Apaseray's courage, adding: "Natalia has been so brave throughout this unfamiliar journey and has not complained once."

Rotary members took her sightseeing in a bid to keep her spirits up as she recovered from the operations.
description: Natalia Apaseray, who was born with rare neurofibromatosis, was tormented by local children who would throw rocks at her
